Dev Enviroment setup

Contents

  • A compiler: Xcode
  • Language: Ruby
  • Web MVC Framework: Rails
  • Relational Database: PostgreSQL
  • Version Control and Deployment: Heroku Toolbelt (includes Git)
  • Software Package Management: Home Brew
  • Text Editor: Sublime Text
  • Browser with devtoolbar: Chrome

Here is what you’ll need to setup your mac to get started with ruby on rails. You will need:

A compiler: Xcode

On a mac Xcode or if you have Xcode 4.4(os x mountain lion) you’ll need to add the Xcode command line tools, which contains a compiler install ruby. 

    xcode->preferences->Downloads

Top of the list, command line tools. (118.5mb) click install.

Language: Ruby

Install RVM(Ruby Version Manager) and ruby
in terminal type: 

    $curl -Lk https://get.rvm.io | bash -s stable --ruby

Ruby 2.0 (installed through RVM in previous point)

check it has gone through, in command line:

        $ ruby -v
        

you should get in return

	$ ruby 2.0.0p247 (2013-06-27 revision 41674) [x86_64-darwin12.3.0]

Web MVC Framework: Rails

Rails , in your terminal type: 

        $ gem install rails  

    once again,when the installation is completed write 

        $ rails -v

    in your terminal ad you should get in response:

        Rails 4.0.0

Relational Database: PostgreSQL

Postgress.app, SQL database, for production. Rails uses SQL3 for development, and sometimes it might be easier to user postgress in development too to avoid problems further down the ile.

Version Control and Deployment: Heroku Toolbelt (includes Git)

Heroku Toolbelt (includes, an heroku comment line client to manager your apps, foreman a local server to check out your app locally, and the easiest way to install Git version control that you’ll also use to push the app to heroku)

Software Package Management: Home Brew

Homebrew, a package management software to simplify installation of gems and libraries.

Text Editor: Sublime Text

a Text Editor, like SublimeTxt2 is a good choise, other options are Vim, textmate, textwrangler. Sublime is not free, but the version you download does not stop working after trial is expired, it just keeps reminding you to buy it every once on a while, but if you are on a budget it will do just fine.

Browser with devtoolbar: Chrome

Google Chrome(to use developer toolbar, to inspect your front end, and various other features).
Alternatevly you can use Firefox, with has his own developer tools as well.
Safari has a developer toolbar as well, but needs to be activated.
